hints_html: Recall that for the usual logarithm, \(f(x) = \ln(x)\), x can’t be zero or negative. Which values of x will make sure that the above function doesn’t end up with a negative or zero value inside the logarithm?
hints_latex:
Recall that for the usual logarithm, $f(x) = \ln(x)$, \emph{x} can't be
zero or negative. Which values of \emph{x} will make sure that the above
function doesn't end up with a negative or zero value inside the
logarithm?
hints_raw: Recall that for the usual logarithm, <math>f(x) = \ln(x)</math>, ''x'' can't be zero or negative.  Which values of ''x'' will make sure that the above function doesn't end up with a negative or zero value inside the logarithm?
question: 1 (b)
sols_html:
The graph of \(g(x) = \ln x\) looks like this:

Using function rules for the graph of \(g(x) = \ln(1 - x)\)

  • the negative in front of the x means the graph has been reflected over the y-axis and

  • (1-x) inside the function means that it is shifted right 1

giving:

If you’ve forgotten the rules used in the first solution (or never learned them), you can also facts about the domain of \(\ln(x)\) to determine where the graph should go.

The domain of the function \(f(x) = \ln (x)\) is \(x > 0\) which can be seen in the graph below.

The graph of \(g(x) = \ln(1-x)\) will have a similar shape, but has a different domain. Let’s test some values to see where the domain of this function is.

[c]@lll@ x-value & & y-value

-2 & \(\ln(1 - (-2)) = \ln(3)\) & \(\ln(3)\)
-1 & \(\ln(1 - (-2)) = \ln(2)\) & \(\ln(2)\)
0 & \(\ln(1 - 0) = \ln(1)\) & 0
1 & \(\ln(1 - 1) = \ln(0)\) & undefined
2 & \(\ln(1 - 2) = \ln(-1)\) & undefined

So clearly this function is defined on the domain \(x < 1\),

suggesting the graph looks something like this:
sols_latex:
If you've forgotten the rules used in the first solution (or never
learned them), you can also facts about the domain of $\ln(x)$ to
determine where the graph should go.

The domain of the function $f(x) = \ln (x)$ is $x > 0$ which can be seen
in the graph below.

\includegraphics[width=0.5\textwidth]{../json_data/MATH110/December_2012/MER_MATH110_December_2012_Question_1b_ln.jpg}

The graph of $g(x) = \ln(1-x)$ will have a similar shape, but has a
different domain. Let's test some values to see where the domain of this
function is.

\begin{longtable}[c]{@{}lll@{}}
x-value & & y-value\\

-2 & $\ln(1 - (-2)) = \ln(3)$ & $\ln(3)$\\
-1 & $\ln(1 - (-2)) = \ln(2)$ & $\ln(2)$\\
0 & $\ln(1 - 0) = \ln(1)$ & 0\\
1 & $\ln(1 - 1) = \ln(0)$ & undefined\\
2 & $\ln(1 - 2) = \ln(-1)$ & undefined\\
\end{longtable}

So clearly this function is defined on the domain $x < 1$,

\includegraphics[width=0.5\textwidth]{../json_data/MATH110/December_2012/MER_MATH110_December_2012_Question_1b_restricted_domain.jpg}

suggesting the graph looks something like this:

\includegraphics[width=0.5\textwidth]{../json_data/MATH110/December_2012/MER_MATH110_December_2012_Question_1b_shifted_ln.jpg}
sols_raw:
The graph of <math>g(x) = \ln x</math> looks like this: 

[[File:MER MATH110 December 2012 Question 1b ln.jpg|300px]]

Using function rules for the graph of <math>g(x) = \ln(1 - x)</math>

* the negative in front of the ''x'' means the graph has been reflected over the y-axis and
* ''(1-x)'' inside the function means that it is shifted right 1

giving:

[[File:MER MATH110 December 2012 Question 1b shifted ln.jpg|300px]]
If you've forgotten the rules used in the first solution (or never learned them), you can also facts about the domain of <math>\ln(x)</math> to determine where the graph should go.  

The domain of the function <math>f(x) = \ln (x)</math> is <math>x > 0</math> which can be seen in the graph below.  

[[File:MER MATH110 December 2012 Question 1b ln.jpg|300px]]

The graph of <math>g(x) = \ln(1-x)</math> will have a similar shape, but has a different domain.  Let's test some values to see where the domain of this function is.  

{| class="wikitable"
|-
! x-value !!  !! y-value
|-
| -2 || <math> \ln(1 - (-2)) = \ln(3) </math> || <math>\ln(3)</math>
|-
| -1 || <math> \ln(1 - (-2)) = \ln(2) </math> || <math>\ln(2)</math>
|-
| 0 || <math> \ln(1 - 0) = \ln(1) </math> || 0
|-
| 1 || <math> \ln(1 - 1) = \ln(0) </math> || undefined
|-
| 2 || <math> \ln(1 - 2) = \ln(-1) </math> || undefined
|}

So clearly this function is defined on the domain <math>x < 1</math>, 

[[File:MER MATH110 December 2012 Question 1b restricted domain.jpg|300px]]

suggesting the graph looks something like this: 

[[File:MER MATH110 December 2012 Question 1b shifted ln.jpg|300px]]
statement_html:
Sketch the graph of the following function.

\(\displaystyle g(x)=\ln(1-x)\)
statement_latex:
Sketch the graph of the following function.

$\displaystyle g(x)=\ln(1-x)$
statement_raw:
Sketch the graph of the following function. 

<math>\displaystyle g(x)=\ln(1-x)</math>
